Description: Gold amulet (or maskeh); inscribed with a hilya, a verbal description of the Prophet's physical and moral qualities, as well as the basmala; Muhammad is described as handsome, fragrant, perfect in stature, round of face and beard, with bluish-black eyes, a large forehead, small ears, long hands and soft fingertips; such amulets were sewn onto clothing, possibly for protection against miscarriage; pierced with six holes.
Bibliographic references: Porter 2011 / Arabic and Persian Seals and Amulets in the British Museum (A100)
Akbarnia et al 2018 / The Islamic World: a History in Objects (p.59, fig.3)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2016-2017 20 Oct-12 Feb, UK, Oxford, Ashmolean Museum, 'Power & Protection: Art and the Supernatural in the Islamic World'
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Hon Sir Charles Augustus Murray
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: Isma'il Pasha, Viceroy of Egypt
